author: Special Correspondent
text:
Nobel laureate Amartya Sen has said that the colonial laws that still govern us must not remain unchallenged.

Delivering the annual Rajendra Mathur Memorial Lecture on “The centrality of the right to dissent” organised by the Editors Guild of India here on Friday, Professor Sen wondered at the continued hold of the colonial laws.

He called for a re-examination of those such as Section 377, which criminalises homosexuality, and Section 295 A of the Indian Penal Code, which he said imposed “unfreedom” on people. “‘Unfreedom’ is no longer imposed on us by our colonial masters. Have these ‘unfreedoms’ really ended? Laws legislated by imperial rulers still govern many parts of our life,” he said.

Under Section 295 A, a person could be sentenced for hurting religious sentiments, “however personal and however bizarrely delicate that outraged sentiment might be”.

“The Constitution does not have anything against having beef or storing it in the refrigerator,” Professor Sen said.

“The problem is not that Indians have turned intolerant. It is to the contrary. We have been much too tolerant even of intolerance. When some people are attacked by organised detractors, they need our support. It is not adequate for us to be offended by their attack,” he said.
title: Re-examine colonial laws, says Amartya
